issues.description: The problem statement and UML refer to a Meal class (with constructor Meal(String, String[])) that is described as 'fully implemented'. The solution repository provides such a Meal class. However, the template repository does not contain an implemented Meal class — instead it contains an Order class with the same constructor and getters. The template also includes an empty Meal.java file. This mismatch (class name and presence) will confuse students: they expect a ready-to-use Meal type from the template but find either an empty Meal file or a differently-named Order class. Students may implement SealSaloon and other logic expecting to use Meal, so the unexpected Order class or missing Meal implementation is a structural inconsistency.
issues.suggested_fix: Provide the Meal class implementation in the template repository matching the problem statement and solution (i.e., Meal with constructor Meal(String, String[]) and the corresponding getters). Remove or rename the extraneous Order class from the template (or clearly document its purpose) so students see the expected Meal type in the starter code. This will align the template with the problem description and the solution reference.

issues.description: The problem statement and the solution refer to the concept/class as 'Meal', but the template repository provides an 'Order' class with the same structure (name + ingredients). This naming mismatch (Meal vs Order) creates a conceptual mapping barrier: students reading the problem expect a ready-to-use Meal class but find an Order class in the starter code, which can cause confusion about which class to use/extend and where to implement SealSaloon functionality.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the template with the problem statement and solution by providing a Meal.java in the template that matches the expected API (name and ingredients getters/constructor). Concretely: rename or duplicate template_repository/src/de/tum/cit/ase/Order.java to template_repository/src/de/tum/cit/ase/Meal.java (and update Main to reference Meal), or replace references to 'Meal' in the problem/solution with 'Order' if renaming is preferred. Prefer creating Meal.java in the template so the problem description and starter code use the same identifier.
